column1: Santa Fe de Nuevo México (English: Holy Faith of New Mexico; shortened as Nuevo México or Nuevo Méjico
column2: and translated as New Mexico in English) was a Kingdom of the Spanish Empire and New Spain
column3: and later a territory of independent Mexico. The first capital was San Juan de los Caballeros (at San Gabriel de Yungue-Ouinge) from 1598 until 1610
column4: and from 1610 onward the capital was La Villa Real de la Santa Fe de San Francisco de Asís. The name "New Mexico"
column6: the government building (Palace of the Governors)
column8: and rule of law were retained when the New Mexico Territory
column9: later the U.S. State of New Mexico
column10: became a part of the United States. The New Mexican citizenry
column16: became citizens of the United States as a result of the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo.

column1: Nuevo México is often incorrectly believed to have taken its name from the nation of Mexico. However
column2: it was named by Spanish explorers who believed the area contained wealthy Amerindian cultures similar to those of the Aztec Empire (centered in the Valley of Mexico)
column3: and called the land the "Santa Fe de Nuevo México".

column1: == Geography ==
Nuevo México was centered on the upper valley of the Rio Grande (Río Bravo del Norte): from the crossing point of Oñate on the river south of Ciudad Juárez
column3: encompassing an area that included most of the present-day U.S. state of New Mexico. It had variably defined borders
column4: and included sections of present-day U.S. states: western Texas
column7: and the Oklahoma panhandle. Actual Spanish settlements were centered at Santa Fe
column8: and extended north to Taos pueblo and south to Albuquerque. Except for the first decade of the province's existence
column9: its capital was in the foothills of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains at the ancient city of La Villa Real de la Santa Fe de San Francisco de Asís (modern day Santa Fe).

column1: === Regions and Municipalities ===
Many of these regions are now US counties and metropolitan areas.
== History ==
=== Spanish colonial province ===
16th centuryOn July 12
column3: Don Juan de Oñate Salazar established the New Spain colony of Santa Fe de Nuevo Méjico at the new village of San Juan de los Caballeros adjacent to the Ohkay Owingeh Pueblo at the confluence of the Río Bravo (Rio Grande) and the Río Chama.  The expedition had been authorized by Philip II to survey the region. Though the Spanish believed that cities of gold such as the ones of the Aztecs
column5: lay to the north in the unexplored territory
column6: the major goal was to spread Catholicism. Other expeditions had taken place before Oñate's 1598 expedition. He was unable to find any riches
column8: he mingled with the Pueblo people and was responsible for the establishment of Spanish rule in the area.

column1: Oñate served as the first governor of the Nuevo México Province from 1598 to 1610. He hoped to make it a separate viceroyalty from New Spain in an original agreement made in 1595
column2: but the terms failed when the Viceroy changed hands in 1596. After a two-year delay and lengthy vetting by the new viceroy
column3: Oñate was finally allowed to cross the Rio Grande River into modern day Texas and New Mexico.

column1: 17th centuryMost of the Spanish missions in Nuevo México were established during the early 17th century with varying degrees of success and failure
column2: oftentimes building directly atop ancient pueblo ruins
column3: and in the centers of pueblos. Some pueblos were friendly to the foreigners
column4: but after cultural differences and the banishment of local religions tensions against the Spanish rose significantly. After compounding misdeeds and overbearing taxes by the Spanish invaders
column5: the indigenous communities rebelled in what is now referred to as the Pueblo Revolt of 1680. This rebellion saw the Spanish expelled from Nuevo México for a period of 12 years and the pueblo people were able to regain lost lands. They returned to battle against the Spanish who sought restoration in 1692 of the conquered holdings. The reoccupation of Santa Fe was accomplished by Diego de Vargas. The province came under the jurisdiction of the Real Audiencia of Guadalajara
column6: with oversight by the Viceroy of New Spain at Mexico City.

column1: 18th centuryIn 1777
column2: with the creation of the Commandancy General of the Provincias Internas
column3: the Nuevo México Province was removed from the oversight of the Viceroy and placed solely in the jurisdiction of the Commandant General of the Provincias Internas. This caused much unrest
column4: due to the sudden lack of representation in Santa Fe for the region of Nuevo México.

column1: === Mexican territory ===
The province remained in Spanish control until Mexico's declaration of independence in 1821. Under the 1824 Constitution of Mexico
column2: it became the federally administered Territory of New Mexico.

column1: The part of the former province east of the Rio Grande was claimed by the Republic of Texas which won its independence in 1836. This claim was disputed by Mexico. In 1841
column2: the Texans sent the Texan Santa Fe Expedition
column3: ostensibly for trade but with hopes of occupying the claimed area
column4: but the expedition was captured by New Mexican troops under New Mexico governor Manuel Armijo.

column1: === American territory ===
The United States inherited the unenforced claim to the east bank with the Texas Annexation in 1845. The U.S. Army under Stephen Kearny occupied the territory in 1846 during the Mexican–American War
column3: and Mexico recognized its loss to the United States in 1848 with the Mexican Cession in the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo.

column1: Texas continued to claim the eastern part
column2: but never succeeded in establishing control except in El Paso. However
column3: in the Compromise of 1850 Texas accepted $10 million in exchange for its claim to areas within and north of the present boundaries of New Mexico and the Texas panhandle.President Zachary Taylor and Abraham Lincoln both proposed that New Mexico immediately become a state to sidestep political conflict over slavery in the territories. New Mexico did not become a state until January 1912.
